Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2012 08:29AM Helmie wrote: Hi Pooka, you really have a great conversation going here. I welcome you to our ever growing group, and just want to jump in to underscore what others already have said here. Yes, you definitely NEED to be on Zometa, or Xgeva. You also NEED to be on Herceptin, because of your Her2 status. Zometa, or Xgeva is given in addition to whatever AI, or chemo you might be on, and so is Herceptin. That your onc has not put you these drugs, I think is irresponsible. I'm on Xgeva, which is only a once a month little shot in the arm. Xgeva is proven not to be hard on your kidneys, while Zometa sometimes can cause kidney problems. Both drugs save your bone strength. Herceptin is a must for you too, unless you have a serious heart issue. I think you need to see a different onc, even if it is just for a 2nd opinion. Maybe you look for an onc that specializes in BC. Your onc might not have that many BC patients. His expertise might be a totally different kind of cancer. I wish you good luck, and success with your upcoming appointments, and treatment plans. Please keep us posted. (((Hugs))) Helmie

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2011 11:33AM Helmie wrote: Hi Banana, you found a good web site to come to for support. Here are a lot of stage IV fighters with a wealth of knowledge. Usually it takes at least a week to get the result of the Her2 status. Has the dx been too recent for having a result yet? Anyway, I was on Arimidex for one year. Never heard of skin peeling. The most disabling SE for me was arthritis pain in my hands. It got so bad, that my onc switched me to Femara. There are a lot of anti hormon drugs available to which her onc can switch her. I agree with Chickadee, your moms onc should put her on Zometa or Xgeva to strengthen her bones. Both drugs are given in the Dr. office. I'm on Xgeva, which is a shot in the arm ones a month - very easy. Best wishes for you and your mom. Please come back, and visit this site often. Hugs, Helmie
Posts.Title: My mom has recently been diagnosed. Please help! Banana83 Banana83

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2012 11:50AM Helmie wrote: Hi Lynn, Faslodex shots worked pretty well for me for about 8 to 9 months. I'm also still getting monthly Xgeva shots. Really did not have any SEs to speak off. My onc also added Zoladex for about 3 months, while I was on Faslodex. I had no SEs from the Zoladex either, but it didn't do any good either. I had some short runs with Halaven (Eribulin), and Navelbine. Both are fairly mild chemos when it comes to the SEs. However, both caused hair thinning. Afinitor, the chemo your onc recommends, is a very strong drug. Lot's of unpleasant SEs. There is an Afinitor 2012 thread here in the stage IV forum. The more I read about Afinitor, the less I like it. My onc also had told me about a clinical trial at MDA in Houston, with Afinitor and Arimidex. I made an appt there, but I don't think I will go on that particular trial. You have so many options. Your onc should be able to find something gentler, and not so very toxic. Good luck, and gentle hugs, Helmie

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2012 11:56AM Helmie wrote: Hi Rosasmommy, would you loose the pain in the donor site too, if you would opt for option 2? If that's the case, I think I would choose that one. However, you are the only person who can make the final decision on this. Maybe after some time living with no breast you have the option of just getting an implant? The option I personally least like is option 3, but that's just me. I had tram flap reconstruction done on my left breast as I was first dx almost 14 years ago. I had a recurrence in 2007 in the chest wall underneath the tram flap. The surgery to remove the tumor destroyed my reconstructed breast. So now I'm wearing a prosthesis. I was told, my plastic surgeon could maybe reconstruct the breast with an implant, but I have not done that yet. Whatever you decide, I wish you luck and success, and most of all "no pain". Hugs, Helma

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2011 11:29AM Helmie wrote: Hi Kathy, I'm on Xgeva, but I was told it is very similar to Zometa. My onc nurse told me that this med does not really fight the cancer, it only strengthens the bones, so they don't break so easily. I'm on Faslodex, and Zoladex to keep the cancer at bay, which is working thus far (since March). What other meds are you on? Chemo or AIs or both? Maybe my understanding of zometa is wrong, but if it's correct you should not have reason to worry about progression if you lower the zometa dosage, as long as you stay on the other cancer fighting meds. Good luck with your scans, Helmie

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2015 12:56PM Helmie wrote: Carolyn, I'm a little confused too. Your signature does not state that you are HER2+, it states you are ER+/PR- and HER2-. ER+ means you are Estrogen Receptor positive, that's why you were put on Arimidex. I'm also ER+ and HER2- and was put on Arimidex for 1 year and then switched to Femara (Letrozole) which kept me going for another year until my cancer progressed. Since then I have been on different chemo treatments sometimes in combination with Hormonal drugs. I have never been on Herceptin. As far as I know Herceptin is only for people that are HER2+. ((Hugs)) Helmie

Posts.Title: BC Metastasis - Lungs, Liver and Bone gramana gramana

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2012 07:18PM Helmie wrote: Hi Barb, I'm another lung mets sister. However, I'm ER/PR+, Her2-. I was on navelbine only for 4 treatments, 3 weeks on, 1 week off, and then I only got one more treatment, because I had developed a subdural hematoma. Nobody knows why. As I got my first navelbine they gave me aloxi as a pre-med anti-nausea. I had a terrible head ache for 2 days after that. The next week I got zofran, and everything was fine. However, just a day before my scheduled 2nd treatment of the 2nd cycle the head ache was back, my onc cancelled the chemo, and sent me to have a brain MRI done right away, where they discovered the subdural hematoma. I had brain surgery on Dec 5th. My onc did not put me back on the navelbine, because I still show progression, but no brain mets. Yesterday I started a new chemo, Alimta. Hope this one will work. It is actually a lung cancer drug, but back in May last year we had sent a tissue sample to Caris Life Science in TX. Amongst a bunch of other recommendations they think that Alimta might be beneficial. I hope the Navelbine will work for you for a very long time. For the short time I was on this drug, I did not notice any SEs (other then the head aches, which I don't attribute to Navelbine anyway). sending you lots of hugs, Helmie

Posts.Title: Lung mets Anne45 Anne45

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2011 08:38PM Helmie wrote: Hi Paula, I had a thoracentesis done twice, one in Feb, and one in March. I'm on Faslodex, and thus far it seems to keep the effusion under control. You sit on the table with your back to the Doctor. They first numb the area, then they inject local anesthesia (which that hurt), but then when they go in with the tube, you don't feel anything. The fluid drains into a bottle, and you can watch it, it does not hurt. However, there will be a time when you start to cough (that's normal), they keep draining until you tell them that it's starting to hurt. The first time, they drained 1500 cc, and the second time 1300 cc. You gonna be a couple pounds lighter after this. After the first time I did not have that much pain as I had after the second time. You will need some vicodin. Make sure you have some. I'm sorry you have to go through this. It's not fun, but you will feel better later. Good luck, and lots of hugs, Helmie

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 08:22PM Helmie wrote: Hi Jinan, my CA125 has always been high (300+). I first had mets in my right lung, then went into a clinical trial last year in March. The CA125 kept going down every month to about 79 in Aug 2010. Then it started going back up again to 302 in Dec 2010. I left the trial, because my cancer had progressed, and I had bone mets now too. I had all kinds of scans. I have no ovarian cancer. My onc told me the high CA125 is most likely a sign of metastatic disease. I'm stable now with the drugs I'm on since March. My CA125 still lingers around 175. That seems to be the new normal for me. However, with ovarian cancer the CA125 is usually very high, like in the thousands. Your mom seems to have the kind of mets that I have (lung and bones), and she is also ER/PR+ and Her2-, just like me. So hopefully the elevated TM is just an indicator of her metastatic disease, and her onc just needs to change her meds. What meds is she on right now? I'm on Faslodex, Zoladex, and Xgeva. You know, we have stage IV BC, so we all have to be on some kind of tmt for the rest of our life. Thus far there is no cure for stage IV BC. If you go to the doctor with your mom, maybe you want to make a list of questions to ask, incl, ask about the drugs I mentioned. It is wonderful of you that you are so close to your mom, and are concerned about her. It must be hard for you, but I'm sure, your mom appreciates it very much. Stay strong, and please come back here often with all your questions. We are always here for you. Lots of (((Hugs))) for you and your mom, Helmie

Posts.Title: Thanks to all stage 4 sisters past and present stagefree cookie97

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2012 08:20AM Helmie wrote: Hi Lynn, I have no idea where this pain could come from. I have had similar pain experiences in the past. About 5 times over a 1 year period. It always started completely out of the blue. The pain was so intense, that it made me vomit. My whole thoracic area hurt like hell, like a leg cramp that does not go away. Twice, my DH took me to the ER - they never found an explanation. My onc could not figure it out either, because I never had an episode, when I was in his office. One time I was at a pulmonary docs office when I got the pain. It lasted for about 45 min that time. I was crying, crouching on the floor, and begging the doc to give me something for the pain, but he said he could not do that. He had no clue where this pain was coming from either. The last time I had a pain episode was in January. Nothing after that. It just never happened again (keep my fingers crossed). Nobody ever found out the cause of it. So I guess, it must have been a fluke. I had been on all kinds of diff chemo, and hormonal drugs during that one year period. It was a mystery. I wish you will be done with this, and it will not come back ever. The pain is almost too much to bare. I don't wish that on anybody. We all deal with the effects of this disease, and the SEs of the drugs already, we don't need any more mystery pains on top of that. sending you warm ((hugs)), Helmie

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2011 05:32PM Helmie wrote: Thank you Peggy for your advise. I talked to my GI Doc about the stent option. He did not recommend it. The stent can move, and actually disappear into your stomach. Also, when you keep the sphincter open all the time, you can't bent over, or lay flat anymore, because food in your stomach floes freely between your stomach and your esophagus back and ford. You have to almost sit up while sleeping to avoid having food go into your trachea. Anyway, I put a call in to him to talk about Heller Myotomy surgery. Waiting to hear back. I also contacted MD Anderson, and consider traveling to Houston. Thanks again, Helmie

It worked only for just about a week. Ejnova, I'm glad it's working for your father. In my case the Doctors seem to agree that my achalasia is caused by whatever screwed up secretions my BC cells are sending out, which then affect the nerves that control the sphincter function.
Posts.Title: Need help, anybody with Achalasia, or esophageal problems? Helmie imbell

Posts.Content: Helmie wrote: I hope there is somebody out there who has, or had a similar experience than me, and can help. I was diagnosed with lung mets in the beginning of 2010. Went into a clinical trial with Aromasin and a Heat Shock Protein for 10 months. 3 or 4 months into the trial I started having problems getting food from my esophagus into my stomach. Not bad at first, I could still eat small amounts at a time. Anyway, my disease progressed, and I quit the trial in December. Have now bone mets too. By the end of January I was not able to eat anything at all anymore. My sphincter would not open anymore to let food into my stomach. I got a feeding tube in February, and have been in, and out of hospitals a few times since than. I'm only on Faslodex, and Xgeva right now. Was on Eribulin (Halaven) for about 2 cycles, which did not work. I have a tumor on the outside of my esophagus, but it's not obstructing. I had Radiation to that tumor for 3 weeks, and now have to wait until the area has calmed down for the new Ct-scan to show any results. Anyway, I still can't eat. My Onc is at the end of his wits. He has consulted with other Oncs, but nobody seems to have a good answer. My GI Doc proposed a dilation with a 30mm balloon, but there is a risk of perforation. I'm so tired of this feeding tube. I live in FL on the water, but I can't go in it because of the feeding tube. When we have guests, I never can go out for lunch or dinner. Traveling/vacation is a problem. I just hope that there is somebody out there who can give me advise. I can't be the only stage IV BC person with this problem? Please help. "Life is like a box of chocolates. You never know what you're gonna get." (Forrest Gump) - thank God for chocolate and puppy dogs - Dx 2/8/2010, Stage IV, Grade 3, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2011 08:08PM Helmie wrote: Sandilee, I'm on Faslodex since January. Did only the loading dosages until Feb 15. My onc took me off the Faslodex and put me on Halaven (Chemo). My hair started to fall out, thinning a lot. My TM went up again a month later, and my onc took me off the Halaven, and back on Faslodex. My hair continued thinning on the Faslodex. I have less then half the hair I had before. First i thought, it's still from the Halaven, but by now that's not possible anymore. However, it seems to me that the thinning has slowed down lately. So i guess, the hair will not completely fall out, it's just going to be thin. The good news is, since I'm on the Faslodex I'm stable, and I'm not on chemo. Hugs, Helmie
Posts.Title: Hair loss on Faslodex? sandilee redskies

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2013 02:00PM Helmie wrote: Hi Gigi, I haven't been posting anything lately. Went through all kinds of ups and downs over the last months. Anyhow, in July my onc put me back on Abraxane. I had been on it back in 2007 for about 3 months and had done pretty well on it. However, this time my energy level went right to the bottom. White bload count very low, so my onc gave me 1/2 a dose of Neulasta (nasty stuff). It gave me terrible head aches for about a week, but I guess it brought my white count back up. Red blood count was too low as well, so after the 3rd Abraxane dose I got a blood transfusion (2 units). My energy went right back up and I felt so much better. Shortness of breath went away too. If you still feel very tired when you see your onc next time, ask him about a blood transfusion. It works within one day Hugs, Helmie

Do you know how often they will do scans? Usually they do them every 6 to 8 weeks. Good luck and many ((hugs)), Helmie
Posts.Title: Finally - A Treatment Date!! Suze35 cookie97

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2012 10:38PM Helmie wrote: I'm not very good with TM wisdom, but there are usually more then one that get checked. My onc checks them once every 3 to 4 weeks, depending on my tx cycles. Which marker are you talking about? Is it the 27/29, or 15.3? As far as I know these are the ones that specifically relate to BC. So if they are going up, then this might be reason for concern. My onc always checks the 15.3, the CEA, and CA 125. The CA 125 is supposed to be an indicator for ovarian cancer. My CA 125 used to be at over 300, but there was nothing wrong with my ovaries or uterus at all - figure? I was on Alimta (a chemo actually primarily designed for lung cancer) from Jan until May, and my onc added another chemo (VP16) in March. He stopped everything in May because my pet scan showed progression. However, my CA 125 TM was way down to 24, which is normal, but my 15.3 had been steadily creeping up to over 60. So I guess what I'm trying to say, TMs are not really all that reliable. Hope your PET scan will bring you good news. At least you will know for sure what's going on, because they, at least, are very reliable. Good luck and warm hugs, Helmie
Posts.Title: Tumor Markers ? mylifelisa chele

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2011 04:07PM Helmie wrote: Hi Brenna, that really sucks, but you came to the right site to ramble. There are a lot of us with similar thoughts. You are going through the slow process of dealing with this f... disease. I don't really know how it goes, or what is first, being mad, or being in denial. I know we should all end up with the final stage (#5  I guess), which is acceptance. I guess a lot of us never make it to that acceptance stage. Are you seeing an onc in a major medical ctr.? They should have info on support groups in your area. As I was first dx I went to a weekly group meeting, which helped me a lot. There were several woman in their early 30s in that group. We were all really mad together, and that felt good. Anyway, I'm sure you will hear from other stage IV girls real soon on this site. Sorry you had to join us here. Sending you lots of (((Hugs))), Helmie
Posts.Title: I HATE BREAST CANCER Brenna-30yrsold-NYC FireKracker

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2011 06:48PM Helmie wrote: That's to bad Southsider. I have my "Celebrity" oncologist since 1998, as I was first diagnosed with stage II. I have seen other oncs over the years, but always came back to him. He used to travel a lot around the country and the world. He only sees BC patients, and is now over 70 years old, and does not travel that much anymore. He does not want to quit, because he has not gotten it right yet (he says). He knows my name, and my husband. We can always call him on his cell, and he always calls us back. Unfortunately Southsider, your onc might be called a celebrity, but he really is not one, and I hope you will let him have it when you see him next time. Hope you can go back to baby guy, he seems to be in it for the right reasons. Hugs, Helmie

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2014 08:59AM Helmie wrote: My cancer center bills Medicare for my monthly Xgeva shots over $8,300 every time. Medicare declines paying for it every time and then the cancer center has to file an appeal. I think the amount they charge for Xgeva is kinda outrages. How is it even possible for a patient to pay this if their insurance won't? I have never been told by my onc's office that I would have to pay anything, so I guess the appeals must be getting approved. To answer your question; I would just let the onc's office handle it and would not call the insurance company just yet. Maybe the onc's office needs to use a  new billing code. Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2014 05:31PM Helmie wrote: Hi Jill, so sorry to read about your torture scene. I'm glad you decided to get a port. Life is so much easier with it. I'm on my 3rd port, got one in 1998 when I was first diagnosed. Had it taken out after one year. Got the 2nd one in 2007 when I had the recurrence. I kept the port for over 4 years. So now I'm on my 3rd one. I was on Abraxane since last year August. It was working very well for me. My tumor markers went way down. I stopped Abraxane in July this year because I was supposed to have repair surgery on my skull done. However, the whole prep time with seeing all the other doctors involved took too long and my tumor markers started climbing again, even thou I was taking Arimidex and got Faslodex shots. My PET/CT in September showed progression in the lung, bone and 2 lesions in the liver. The liver mets are a new thing for me, just like yours. I got off the Faslodex and Arimidex and are now back on Abraxane. Now I'm a little concerned hearing from you that your liver mets developed while you were on Abraxane. The next time when my tumor markers will be checked will be on Oct. 28. I hope they will start to go down again, if not I might have to switch to AC or just Adriamycin as well. This worries me a little, since I have a small heart murmur and Adriamycin is pretty hart on your heart. Have they told you anything about the heart risk? ((Hugs)) Helmie

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2011 01:01PM Helmie wrote: Hi Stephanie, welcome to our unfortunately ever growing club. I'm on Faslodex and Xgeva as well. Last year I had issues with my right arm. I had pain, and it looked like my right arm was a little swollen. It was always red too, like the blood was not draining properly. I had a venogram, but they did not find a clot. My onc put me on a low dose of coumadin, and after a couple of months my arm was a lot better. I never found out what actually caused my arm problem. It might also be something completely different than what you are experiencing with your legs. I do not have any pain in my legs, just sometimes I think I might have restless leg syndrome at night, which keeps me from getting a good night sleep. I hope your onc will be able to figure it out for you soon. Good luck. Hugs, Helmie

Posts.Content: Helmie wrote: I'm so sad to let you know that our dear friend Claudia (runnr) has lost her battle. I had met her a couple of times for lunch. She was a wonderful person. Her family posted this on her FB page Claudia finally lost her long battle with cancer Sunday night. She had made up her mind Friday morning to not to pursue further treatment and entered Hospice care at the Good Samaritan Hospital Friday evening. Her relief was evident, she lo...oked better than she has in months that evening. She met with her daughters and brother Saturday evening saving her last energy to say goodbye. It was very sad but powerful moment, her words delivered with conviction and authority. With a pain injection she closed her eyes, there were no other words. There will be a memorial service at the Dorsey-Smith Funeral Home on Kirk Road, Lake Worth at a date to be announced near the end of January. Below is a link to a preliminary tribute page. zanhttp://obits.dignitymemorial.com/dignity-memorial/obituary.aspx?n=Claudia-Kugler&lc=4228&pid=168826148&mid=5794625&cid=em.legacy.dm.4228.5794625&eid=sp_sciobitposted I'm heart broken Helm Edited by Mods to remove personally identifiable information "Life is like a box of chocolates. You never know what you're gonna get." (Forrest Gump) - thank God for chocolate and puppy dogs - Dx 2/8/2010, Stage IV, Grade 3, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2011 08:09PM Helmie wrote: Mary-Lou, so wonderful to hear your good news on the bone mets. Hope the Xgeva will work for you for a very long time. I'm a little confused about Xgeva, and the way it works. I started getting monthly shots in January. Had a lesion on my T6 vertebrae. My onc told me that Xgeva is basically just keeping my bones strong, it does not actually heal, or reverse the growth of bone mets. By now I have a small lesion in my left hip bone, one in my #8, and #10 rip. In addition to the Xgeva I have been on Faslodex, Zoladex, Halaven, Estradiol, and Navelbine this year. Starting a new Chemo on Jan 5th - still getting my monthly Xgeva shots too. Since I have more bone mets now then I had when I started on Xgeva, you probably understand why I'm confused (but happy for all of you) when I hear that Xgeva has stabilized, or even healed your bone mets. Hugs, Helmie

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2012 11:25AM Helmie wrote: I'm not sure, because I was on Abraxane as I was already in menopause. However, my first chemo was Adriamycin and Cytoxan. I was pre- menopause then, and the drugs put me right into early menopause. After the AC I took Tamoxifen for 2 years, which kept me in early menopause, but about 6 months after I stopped the Tamoxifen I got my period back. I would guess, if the Abraxane will put you into early menopause, you would come out of it after you're done with the chemo. But it probably depends on whatever drug you're gonna get after the Abraxane. Hugs, Helmie

Posts.Content: May 25, 2012 09:21AM Helmie wrote: Sallyy, my lung mets were discovered in Jan 2010 - multiple nodules in the right pleural area (all 3 lobes) - had a biopsy in Feb 2010, which confirmed metastatic disease. I do not have much discomfort from these nodules, however, over time I had fluid building up in the pleural lining of my right lung. Had to have a thoracentesis several times. It seems like it all depends on which chemo, or drugs I'm on. Some make it worse, some reduce the fluid. Thus far, all the tx I've been getting since 2010 have worked for a while, and when they stopped working, I moved on to another one.  Good luck, and hugs, Helmie

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2012 11:08AM Helmie wrote: Hi Kay, the difference is; * NED means "no evidence of disease", which I was after my surgery in 2007 until my lung mets were discovered in 2009. * Remission was happening while I was in tx, because the tumors were shrinking, but never went away, so the disease was still present. * If the tumors stop decreasing, but are still there, you have stable disease. Of course all that goes out the window, as soon as the tumors start growing again.  Hope this helps, hugs, Helmie

Posts.Content: May 25, 2012 05:14PM Helmie wrote: Sally what tx are you on right now? Most likely your onc would not change the tx plan, even if the nodules in your lung are confirmed as MBC. As long as scans do not show any progression, the current tx is working. However, I'm sure if the nodules in your lung grow larger your onc would immediately call for a biopsy, and change your tx plan. Please do not worry too much right now. Just make sure your onc follows up with new scans at least once every 3 months. Maybe you can talk him into having another scan in 8 weeks (that's usually the interval that pharma companies use when testing new drugs). Good luck, and lots of hugs, Helmie
Posts.Title: Lung mets sallyyy Cydz

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2011 09:11PM Helmie wrote: Hi Tammie, PET scans are very expensive, that's why the ins-co might give you a hard time. Your onc should be able to justify to do the PET. As far as I know, a PET is more sensitive, and picks things up better than a bone scan, or a CT. My ins-co pays for a PET twice a year. My bone lesions were found with a PET, and not with a bone scan. Hope you can get it done, and your ins-co will pay for it. Good luck. Hugs, Helmie

Posts.Title: Asthmatics with Lung Mets Karen2012 Lynne

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2012 11:44PM - edited Jan 13, 2012 11:46PM by Helmie Cheryl, I'm dealing with lung mets (too many nodules to count) since Jan. 2010. In Jan. 2011 I had progression to the bones, and even more lung nodules. I tried  Eribulin, and Navelbine, and also Faslodex, and Zoladex. Nothing seems to work for me. In March and April 2011 I had to have the fluid drained out of my right lung lining. Then I was fine for several months, and had the procedure done again last Nov. Now I have another appointment scheduled for next week. Lots of fluid again. I don't understand how you describe your moms pleural fluid building up in pockets in different areas inside the lung, and also you're talking about one, or two large tumors. I have fluid built up only in the lining. The more fluid builds up, the more my right lung gets squeezed together, and breathing becomes harder. It sounds like your mom's disease progression to her lung is completely different then mine. I started a new chemo this month, Alimta, which was designed to fight Mesothelioma. Hope that one will do the trick. Maybe something to think about for future treatments for your mom too. This drug is just an out-of-the-box approach for me. I hope your mom will feel relief after the tap, and the Eribulin will work for her for a long time. Hugs, Helmie

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2014 03:07PM Helmie wrote: Hi shaM, sorry to hear about your mom. I have metastatic disease in my bones and in my right lung since 2009. You write that your mom has lung cancer. Is that what her oncologist told her it is? If this is really lung cancer and not metastatic breast cancer which has spread to her lungs, her treatment should be different. If your mom has breast cancer which has spread to her bones and lungs the treatment with Aromasin for the cancer and Zometa for bone strengthening will hopefully help her. However, I would recommend to have her oncologist check her lungs and see if she might have fluid build up, since she is in pain and can't breath very well. I used to have a lot of fluid build up in my lung and needed frequent thoracentesis procedures. These help a lot, breathing is so much easier afterwards. How often does her oncologist check her blood and her tumor markers? If the markers do not go down from the Aromasin alone she probably needs to have a chemo drug added to her treatment. There are so many chemo drugs out there and some of them have very tolerable side effects.   Since August I'm on Abraxane ones a week and for the bones I get an Xgeva shot ones a month. So far so good, my tumor markers have gone down a lot, and I feel pretty good too.  Aromasin, which I took back in 2010, did not work for me. My cancer progressed. But that's how it goes once cancer becomes metastatic. Drugs work for a while, and then they stop working and the cancer progresses. So you have to move on to the next drug, and the next, and the next. Metastatic breast cancer is not curable. Your mom will have to be in some form of treatment for the rest of her life, which can be many years as you can see from the stories of so many here on this web site. Good luck to your mom. It's so wonderful that you are there for her during this tough time. Sending you both lots of warm (((Hugs))), Helmie

Posts.Title: 10-10-10 ITS MY BIRTHDAY TODAY! Anne45 Anne45

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2014 10:57AM Helmie wrote: Hi shaM, I have bone and lung metastasis, but I have never gotten radiation treatment for shortness of breath. As far as I know radiation treatment is used to shrink tumors and/or relieve bone pain. My lung mets caused me to have fluid build up in the lining of my lung. The more fluid build up - the more shortness of breath. I had to have several thoracentesis procedures done (which is the draining of the fluid). After each procedure my breathing improved immediately. do you know if your mom had a thoracentesis done? Zometa is for bone strengthening and Aromasin is an aromatase inhibitor which blocks estrogen. Since she is only on Aromasin for 4 days I doubt that it helped her breathing. I'm not on Zometa, I'm on ones a month shots of Xgeva, and yes, I have to stay on this drug for a very long time, maybe forever. It depends on the SEs, how severe they are, and how well your mom handles them, her medical oncologist might switch her from Zometa to Xgeva.  Hope this will help a little. Hugs and good luck to you and your mom, Helmie
Posts.Title: Bone and lung metastas, Help please shaM Lynne

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2012 07:39PM - edited Jan 16, 2012 07:42PM by Helmie Hi Cheryl, the drained fluid will be tested for mets, I'm sure. It does not always have metastatic disease. I had my right lung drained several times. The fluid always tested neg for mets. However I have cancer nodules inside the lining, where the fluid builds up, as well as all throughout my right lung. The tumors, or nodules in the lung are most likely the reason for the fluid build up. If it would be the drugs causing this build up, wouldn't we have fluid build up in both lungs? I don't know obviously, just thinking. ((Hugs)) Helmie

Posts.Title: Terrible taste? dianaleo ejnova

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2011 10:59PM Helmie wrote: Hi Sue, in 2007 after 8.5 years since my first dx, I had a recurrence in my chest wall, and a tumor on my sternum. I had all the tumors surgically removed, then chemo for 4 months, then rad. After that my markers were down, and my onc put me on AIs only. They called it stage III, because the recurrence was local. I had NED until 2010. I had progression to my right lung, and then they called it stage IV BC. However, what I wanted to say is, if they are able to surgically remove the tumor, and you get through treatment OK, you will hopefully end up having NED for a long time. Hang in there, good luck, and hugs, Helmie
